{{Refimprove|date=November 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Use British English|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox military installation |name =RAF North Creake |ensign=[[File:Ensign of the Royal Air Force.svg|90px]] |native_name = |partof = |location = |nearest_town = [[Fakenham]], [[Norfolk]] |country = England |image = |alt = |caption = |image2 = |alt2 = |caption2 = |type = [[Royal Air Force station]] |coordinates = {{Coord|52|54|38|N|000|49|17|E|region:GB_type:airport|display=inline,title}} |latd =52 | latm =54 | lats =38 | latNS = N |longd =000 | longm =49 | longs =17 | longEW = E |coordinates_type = airport |coordinates_region = GB |pushpin_map = Norfolk |pushpin_map_caption = Shown within Norfolk |pushpin_label = RAF North Creake |ownership = [[Air Ministry]] |operator = [[Royal Air Force]] |controlledby = |site_other_label = <!-- for renaming "Other facilities" in infobox to something more fitting --> |site_other = <!-- for other sorts of facilities - radar types etc --> |area = |code = |built = {{Start date|1942}} |used = 1943-{{End date|1947}} |builder = |materials = |height = |fate = |condition = |battles = |events = |commander = <!-- current commander --> |commanders = <!-- past notable commander(s) --> |garrison = |occupants = |open_to_public = |website = |image3 = |alt3 = |caption3 = |IATA = |ICAO = |FAA = |TC = |LID = |GPS = |WMO = |elevation = {{Convert|73|m|0}} |r1-number = 01/19 |r1-length = {{Convert|1315|m|0}} |r1-surface = [[Concrete]] |r2-number = 04/22 |r2-length = {{Convert|1720|m|0}} |r2-surface = Concrete |r3-number = 13/31 |r3-length = {{Convert|1315|m|0}} |r3-surface = Concrete |airfield_other_label = <!-- for renaming "Other facilities" in infobox to something more fitting --> |airfield_other = <!-- for other sorts of airfield facilities - launchpads, airship hangars etc --> |footnotes = <!-- catchall in case it's needed to preserve something in infobox that doesn't work in new code, historical building reference number, etc--> }}
'''Royal Air Force North Creake''' or more simply '''RAF North Creake''' is a former [[Royal Air Force]] [[Royal Air Force station|station]] located {{Convert|3.3|mi}} southwest of [[Wells-next-the-Sea]], [[Norfolk]] and {{Convert|5.7|mi}} northwest of [[Fakenham]], Norfolk, England.
==History== ===Second World War===
Originally used in 1941 as a decoy site for [[RAF Docking]], construction of this Class A airfield began in October 1942, with the station being provided with accommodation for 2,951 male and 411 female staff. The airfield had 36 loop type hardstandings, two T2 hangars and one B1 hangar.
By December 1943 the airfield had passed to [[No. 100 Group RAF|100 Group]], although it did not immediately become operational as consideration was given to upgrading the airfield to Very Heavy Bomber Standard. In the event, this did not take place, with [[RAF Sculthorpe]] being selected for upgrade.
[[Short Stirling|Short Stirling III's]] from [[No. 199 Squadron RAF|199 Squadron]] arrived in May 1944 to complete [[Chaff (countermeasure)|Window]] and [[No. 515 Squadron RAF#Mandrel|Mandrel]] operations against enemy radar tracking of Bomber Command raids, however in during March 1945 these were changed to [[Handley Page Halifax|Handley Page Halifax III's]]. In September 1944, No. 199's 'C' Flight was used to re-form [[No. 171 Squadron RAF|171 Squadron]], who contributed to 100 Group's radio counter-measures activities with Halifaxes.<ref name="CT">{{cite web|url=http://www.controltowers.co.uk/N/North_Creake.htm|title=RAF North Creake airfield |publisher=Control Towers|accessdate=3 November 2014}}</ref>
Seventeen aircraft were lost during operations from the airfield, eight Stirling's and nine Halifax's.
===Post-war===
After the War, the airfield was used for the storage and scrapping of aircraft, mostly [[de Havilland Mosquito]]es by [[No. 274 Maintenance Unit RAF]].<ref name="CT"/>
==Current use== [[File:North Creake Airfield - geograph.org.uk - 299498.jpg|thumb|A small part of the airfield is now business premises of ABN animal feedstuffs. In the foreground are moss covered [[Nissen huts]]]]
The RAF relinquished the station in 1947, and the area is now used for agriculture, though some evidence of runways, buildings and facilities remains.
The control tower survives, and has been converted into a house, offering bed and breakfast.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.controltowerstays.com/|title=Welcome to The Control Tower|publisher=The Control Tower B & B|accessdate=3 November 2014}}</ref> The Stagecoach in Norfolk bus company in March 2016 registered the setting up of an Operating Centre on this site for 10 vehicles.
==See also== *[[List of former Royal Air Force stations]] *[[List of Royal Air Force aircraft squadrons]]
